title: What is the state of unconsciousness in hypnotism and what are its effects?
first_phrase: In the last part of this text, the author discusses the suggestions and experiences that can be induced during hypnosis. The author notes that while some subjects are more susceptible to certain suggestions than others, many experiences can be induced, such as changes in personality, sensory perception, and even physical sensations. However, the author also acknowledges that there are exceptions to the general patterns of hypnotic experiences. The text highlights the importance of recognizing the reality of hypnotic phenomena and calls upon the scientific community, particularly the medical field, to acknowledge and further investigate these phenomena.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the study of mesmerism and magnetism in the late 19th century featured a wide range of theories, techniques, and publications that have been highly influential in the development of hypnosis and psychology. From the controversial claims of Dr. Philips to the groundbreaking ideas of the Baron du Potet and the practical manuals of Lafontaine and Germer-Baillière, these works have shaped our understanding of the human mind and the power of suggestion. Despite the many misunderstandings and hoaxes surrounding this field, it remains an important area of research and exploration for scholars and practitioners today.
